title.value: On the Identifiability of Quantized Factors
title.justification: This is the title of the paper presented at the 3rd Conference on Causal Learning and Reasoning.
title.quote: On the Identifiability of Quantized Factors

extractions.description: The paper introduces and formalizes a relaxed form of representation identifiability called quantized factor identifiability. It proves the identifiability of quantized latent factors under a generic nonlinear diffeomorphism and presents a comprehensive proof of the recovery of these factors, assuming independent discontinuities in their density.

type.justification: The paper revisits and tackles the theoretical problem of unsupervised identifiability of latent factors and provides a comprehensive proof of their recovery.
type.quote: However, in the present theoretical work, we revisit and tackle the problem of fully unsupervised identifiability of latent factors, the most challenging setting. ... We introduce and formalize a novel relaxed form of representation identifiability: quantized factor identifiability.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on identifiability and disentanglement of causal factors in representation learning.
name.quote: Disentanglement aims to recover meaningful latent ground-truth factors from the observed distribution solely, and is formalized through the theory of identifiability.

name.justification: The paper aims to disentangle meaningful latent ground-truth factors through the theory of identifiability.
name.quote: Disentanglement aims to recover meaningful latent ground-truth factors from the observed distribution solely, and is formalized through the theory of identifiability.

name.justification: The paper revisits the identifiability problem in the context of nonlinear ICA and builds on the theory to introduce quantized factor identifiability.
name.quote: Unsupervised disentanglement of latent factors has been found impossible in the general nonlinear setting in the absence of further inductive bias (Locatello et al., 2019). This result echoes an older identification impossibility result on nonlinear Independent Component Analysis (Hyvärinen and Pajunen, 1999).

name.justification: The paper discusses the identifiability of quantized, grid-like representations and provides proof for their recovery.
name.quote: We relax the notion of identifiability of continuous factors to that of identifiability of quantized continuous factors. The promise of quantized, grid-like representations has been argued empirically in both machine learning and neuroscience.

name.justification: The Hausdorff Factorized Support (HFS) model is used in the experiments for comparison purposes.
name.quote: We compare our model with linear ICA and show that our model is able to learn a factorized representation of the factors, while Fast ICA (Hyvärinen, 1999) fails due to the correlation of the factors violating the independence assumption, as illustrated in Figure 4. HFS also learns the reconstructed factors up to a rotation (but no shearing), even though its factorized support assumption is satisfied, showing that in this case our criterion is effective in aligning the factors with the axes.

is_contributed.justification: The model was used for comparison in the experiments, not a novel contribution of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: HFS also learns the reconstructed factors up to a rotation (but no shearing), even though its factorized support assumption is satisfied, showing that in this case our criterion is effective in aligning the factors with the axes.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed in experiments to compare with the proposed method.
is_executed.quote: Training is done using stochastic gradient descent with a step size of 0.0001 and a batch size of 5000 samples.

is_compared.justification: The model is compared numerically to other models like ICA in the experiments.
